intro: Carlina atractyloides, commonly known as the meadow cudweed, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small daisies. The plant typically grows in meadows, grasslands, and woodland edges, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the flowers are yellow with a distinctive purple-tinged center. Carlina atractyloides is known for its medicinal properties and has been used traditionally in herbal remedies.
